note.p: MS Codex 906, Philadelphia, PA, University of Pennsylvania (olim MS French 1). French, last quarter of the fifteenth century. Contains Roman de la Rose (folios 1-340).
Paper, 300 x 210 mm 340 folios. (Modern foliation begins on fol. 2, i.e. fol. 2 labeled “1” in modern hand – since foliation skips fol. 318, count comes out the same by end.)

Paper, in good condition aside from worm/insect holes through first couple of quires. The first nineteen quires contain numerous examples of a watermark matching Briquet 1799. Quire XX, copied by a different scribe, contains Briquet 1548 and 1701. Quire XXI contains a watermark very similar to Briquet 1546, with the exception that the three “arrows” are simply straight lines with no points on the end, as well as another watermark not found in Briquet.
Briquet numbers from C. M. Briquet, Les Filigranes: Dictionnaire Historique des Marques du Papier dès leur Apparition vers 1282 jusqu'en 1600. 4 vols. New York: Hacker Art Books, 1966:
1799: “31X44. Toulouse, 1474. A. MUN., CC. 1106 : Pièces à l’appui des cptes.”
1548: “31X44. Châteaudun, 1463. A. EURE-ET-LOIR, E. 2739: Tabellionage. Var. ident. : Blois, 1466; Poitiers, 1466-74; Bretagne, 1472.”
1701: “31,5X44. Châteaudun, 1454. A. EURE-ET-LOIR, E. 2734. : Tabellionage. Var. ident. : Orleans, 1457; Châteaudun, 1457-65; Champagne (Sarthe), 1458; Angers, 1464
1546: “31X44. Châteaudun, 1457. IBID. E. 2735 : id. Var. simil. : Blois, 1496.

On the basis of this evidence, we are able to establish a terminus a quo for the manuscript of 1474. It is interesting to note, however, that quires XX and XXI are on paper dating as much as twenty years prior to this time, and that each is the work of a different scribe.

Bound in gatherings of 16 with the exception of quire XIX. No quire numbers. Signatures at bottom right; note that signature a begins on fol. 2 (the first folio with text), and thus runs ai-avii (i.e. not ai-aviii, which one would expect in a quire of 16 leaves). Alphabet does not include j in labeling quires. Quire XX, where there is a change of hand, simply numbers first eight leaves i-viij, as does XXI (where there is another change of hand). Quire XXI is also numbered, although there is no apparent need for this since it is a bifolium. Catchwords at bottom center, often cropped.

i + 340 + i. Bound in gatherings of 16 with the exception of quire XIX. No quire numbers. Signatures at bottom right; note that signature a begins on fol. 2 (the first folio with text), and thus runs ai-avii (i.e. not ai-aviii, which one would expect in a quire of 16 leaves). Alphabet does not include j in labeling quires. Quire XX, where there is a change of hand, simply numbers first eight leaves i-viij, as does XXI (where there is another change of hand). Quire XXII is also numbered, although there is no apparent need for this since it is a bifolium. Catchwords at bottom center, often cropped. Modern foliation begins on fol. 2, i.e. fol. 2labeled “1” in modern hand – since foliation skips fol. 318, count comes out to 340, which is accurate, by the end. In this description, pages are numbered sequentially beginning with fol. 1r, as indicated in the collation.

Ruled in drypoint, with only four lines to define text block; no ruling for individual lines of verse. No prickings. Single text block with one column of text per leaf; text block varies in size, usually 190mm x 100-110mm. Usually 33-35 lines in first twenty quires; 31-34 in quire XX; 31-33 in quire XXI; 33-37 lines in XXII.

The main scribal hand, using brown ink and a cursiva script, is responsible for the first nineteen quires. A second hand copied quire XX; XXI in a hand similar to main scribe, but likely a third scribe. Lines following rubricated initials use a larger, slightly more formal script. Corrections are sparse, although there are a few (see, e.g., lining through at bottom of fol. 306). No running heads.

A number of rubricated headings throughout, usually with guide line written in brown ink in the margin; these marginal guides often partially cropped. Numerous two-line rubricated capitals throughout. The initial of each line (other than two-line rubricated initials) touched in yellow.

No line fillers. There are no miniatures or illuminations, but spaces approximately nine lines in height were left for them; these are frequent in the beginning of the manuscript, but become progressively less so and eventually disappear.

Blind-stamped contemporary calf, rebacked (Zacour – Hirsch). No clasps or metallic pieces. One paper flyleaf each at beginning and end, thus i + 340 + i. Title on spine: “LE ROMAN DE LA ROSE” “DE JEAN MEUN DIT CLOPINEL” “MANUSCRIPT DU XV ? [S]IECLE.” Parchment binding fragment shows between folios 338 and 339.

According to the University of Pennsylvania catalog entry, “Sold in the Ashburnham collection at auction at Sotheby’s, 10 June 1901, lot 607,” and “Purchased from Librairie J. Thiebaud, 1950.” Written on inside front cover: “Archives du Bibliophile XV Bulletin No.” and a signature that Zacour-Hirsch transcribe “Marcel(?).” On folio 2r: “Delaplanches.” A scrap of paper containing verses 64-73, apparently by main scribe’s hand is pasted on fol. 1.
Previous descriptions:
Zacour, Norman P. and Rudolf Hirsch. Catalogue of Manuscripts in the Libraries of the University of Pennsylvania to 1800. Philadelphia: U of Pennsylvania P, 1965. p. 54.

p.hi: Archives du bibliophile; ou, Bulletin de l'amateur de livres et du libraire. Bulletin XV.

note.p: See also call number “Ms. Codex 906” in the Penn Libraries Catalog, available online.
Description by Timothy L. Stinson
